info.long_name: Primary care access by count
info.short_description: Count of primary care physicians based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of primary care physicians based on provider locations. Address data was collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: There are " + primacare_cnt + " primary care physicians in " + region_name
info.name: WebMD Physician Directory

info.long_name: Primary care access score (2-step enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of primary care physician accessibility based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description:
Primary care access score based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of physicians per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for physicians (population served by physicians). Provider address data was collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
Citations:
Wei Luo. Using a GIS-based floating catchment method to assess areas with shortage of physicians. Health & Place, 10(1):1 – 11, 2004. doi:10.1016/S1353-8292(02)00067-9.
Wei Luo and Yi Qi. An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (e2sfca) method for measuring spatial accessibility to primary care physicians. Health & Place, 15(4):1100 – 1107, 2009. doi:10.1016/j.healthplace.2009.06.002.
Wei Luo and Fahui Wang. Measures of spatial accessibility to health care in a GIS environment: synthesis and a case study in the Chicago region. Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design, 30(6):865–884, 2003. doi:10.1068/b29120.
Saxon, James, Julia Koschinsky, Karina Acosta, Vidal Anguiano, Luc Anselin, and Sergio Rey. (2020). An Open Software Environment to Make Spatial Access Metrics More Accessible. University of Chicago: Center for Spatial Data Science. Preprint doi:10.13140/RG.2.2.12396.28807
info.statement: The primary care accessibility score for " + region_name + " is " +  primcare_e2sfca
info.name: WebMD Physician Directory

info.long_name: Dental care access by count
info.short_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of dentists based on provider locations. Address data was collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: There are " + dent_cnt + " dentists in " + region_name
info.name: WebMD Physician Directory

info.long_name: Dental care access score (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of dental care accessibility based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description:
Dental care access score based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of dentists per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for dentists (population served by dentists). Provider address data was collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
Citations:
Wei Luo. Using a GIS-based floating catchment method to assess areas with shortage of physicians. Health & Place, 10(1):1 – 11, 2004. doi:10.1016/S1353-8292(02)00067-9.
Wei Luo and Yi Qi. An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (e2sfca) method for measuring spatial accessibility to primary care physicians. Health & Place, 15(4):1100 – 1107, 2009. doi:10.1016/j.healthplace.2009.06.002.
Wei Luo and Fahui Wang. Measures of spatial accessibility to health care in a GIS environment: synthesis and a case study in the Chicago region. Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design, 30(6):865–884, 2003. doi:10.1068/b29120.
Saxon, James, Julia Koschinsky, Karina Acosta, Vidal Anguiano, Luc Anselin, and Sergio Rey. (2020). An Open Software Environment to Make Spatial Access Metrics More Accessible. University of Chicago: Center for Spatial Data Science. Preprint doi:10.13140/RG.2.2.12396.28807
info.statement: The dentist accessibility score for " + region_name + "is" + value
info.name: WebMD Physician Directory

info.long_name: OBGYN care access by count
info.short_description: Count of OBGYNs based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of OBGYN care providers based on provider locations. Address data was collected from WebMD's online Physician Directory.
info.statement: There are " + obgyn_cnt + " OBGYNs in " + region_name
info.name: WebMD Physician Directory

info.long_name: OBGYN care access score (2 step-enhanced floating catchment areas)
info.short_description: Index of OBGYN care accessibility based on supply and demand of providers
info.long_description:
OBGYN care access score based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of OBGYNs per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Weights are defined for the demand for OBGYNs (population served by OBGYNs). Provider address data was collected from WebMD's online physician directory.
Citations:
Wei Luo. Using a GIS-based floating catchment method to assess areas with shortage of physicians. Health & Place, 10(1):1 – 11, 2004. doi:10.1016/S1353-8292(02)00067-9.
Wei Luo and Yi Qi. An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (e2sfca) method for measuring spatial accessibility to primary care physicians. Health & Place, 15(4):1100 – 1107, 2009. doi:10.1016/j.healthplace.2009.06.002.
Wei Luo and Fahui Wang. Measures of spatial accessibility to health care in a GIS environment: synthesis and a case study in the Chicago region. Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design, 30(6):865–884, 2003. doi:10.1068/b29120.
Saxon, James, Julia Koschinsky, Karina Acosta, Vidal Anguiano, Luc Anselin, and Sergio Rey. (2020). An Open Software Environment to Make Spatial Access Metrics More Accessible. University of Chicago: Center for Spatial Data Science. Preprint doi:10.13140/RG.2.2.12396.28807
info.statement: The OBGYN access score for " + region_name + " is " + obgyn_e2sfca
info.name: WebMD Physician Directory

info.long_name: Percent of population without health insurance
info.short_description: Percent of the population self-reported to not be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan
info.long_description: Percent of the population self-reported to not be currently covered by any type of health insurance or health coverage plan. This data comes from Question 16 of the American Community Survey.
info.statement: no_hlth_ins_pct +  " percent of the population has no health insurance in " + region_name
info.name: American Community Survey

info.long_name: Preventable hospital stays per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
info.short_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees
info.long_description: Rate of hospital stays for ambulatory-care sensitive conditions per 100,000 Medicare enrollees. Ambulatory care refers to diagnoses that are usually treatable in outpatient settings. This data is based on Medicare claims and comes from County Health Rankings.
info.statement: prevent_hosp_rate + " percent of the hospitalizations in " +  region_name + " were preventable

info.long_name: Access to day care by count
info.short_description: Count of day cares based on provider locations
info.long_description: Count of day cares based on provider locations. Address data was collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool.
info.statement: There are " + daycare_cnt + " daycares in " + region_name
info.name: Virginia Department of Social Services

info.long_name: Day care access score (3-step floating catchment area)
info.short_description: Index of day care accessibility based on supply of and demand for providers
info.long_description:
Primary care access score based on 2-step enhanced floating catchment areas. This method is an aggregation of day care facilities per population ratios weighted by distance or travel time in each catchment area (area within which a provider is accessible). Provider address data was collected from Virginia Department of Social Services day care search tool. 
Citations:
Wei Luo. Using a GIS-based floating catchment method to assess areas with shortage of physicians. Health & Place, 10(1):1 – 11, 2004. doi:10.1016/S1353-8292(02)00067-9.
Wei Luo and Yi Qi. An enhanced two-step floating catchment area (e2sfca) method for measuring spatial accessibility to primary care physicians. Health & Place, 15(4):1100 – 1107, 2009. doi:10.1016/j.healthplace.2009.06.002.
Wei Luo and Fahui Wang. Measures of spatial accessibility to health care in a GIS environment: synthesis and a case study in the Chicago region. Environment and Planning B: Planning and Design, 30(6):865–884, 2003. doi:10.1068/b29120.
Saxon, James, Julia Koschinsky, Karina Acosta, Vidal Anguiano, Luc Anselin, and Sergio Rey. (2020). An Open Software Environment to Make Spatial Access Metrics More Accessible. University of Chicago: Center for Spatial Data Science. Preprint doi:10.13140/RG.2.2.12396.28807
info.statement: The daycare accessibility score for " + region_name +  " is " + daycare_norm_3sfca
info.name: Virginia Department of Social Services

Percent of population with broadband

info.long_name: Percent of population with cable fiber internet or DSL

info.name: Ookla

info.name: Virginia Department of Education

info.long_name: Percent  of population with post-high school education

info.name: Virginia Department of Social Services
